CZM-16 200 0.39 CZM-C 179 0.73 Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5 core-shell catalyst for N2O decomposition Tao Meng a Nan Ren b ⁎⁎ Zhen Ma a ⁎ a Shanghai Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Particle Pollution and Prevention (LAP3), Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433, China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Particle Pollution and Prevention (LAP3) Department of Environmental Science and Engineering Fudan University Shanghai 200433 China b Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Department of Chemistry, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433, China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials Department of Chemistry Fudan University Shanghai 200433 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 21 6564 2997; fax: +86 21 6564 3597. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Silicalite-1 particles with an average size of 260nm were used as seeds to prepare Silicalite-1@ZSM-5 core-shell crystals with sizes on the order of 500nm. A Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5 catalyst was then prepared by ion exchange with copper acetate. Upon appropriate pretreatment in He at 500°C, the core-shell catalyst showed much higher activity in N2O decomposition than Cu-ZSM-5 prepared using commercial ZSM-5 as the precursor. Characterization of relevant samples was conducted employing N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, ICP, XRF, SEM, TEM, XPS, CO-IR, H2-TPR, and O2-TPR. It was found that Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5 has more dimetric Cu+ upon thermal pretreatment in He. In addition, less O2 can be adsorbed on Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5. Both factors contribute to the much higher activity of Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5. The effect of co-fed O2 and H2O vapor on the catalytic performance was also studied. Keywords Core-shell zeolite Cu-ZSM-5 N2O decomposition 1 Introduction Zeolites are aluminosilicates with well defined crystalline structures/topologies and micropores. They have thermal stability, acid properties, as well as adsorption and ion-exchange capacities. Therefore, they have been frequently used as catalysts, adsorbents, and ion-exchangers in practical applications. In particular, ZSM-5 (a zeolite with MFI framework topology) and its derived catalysts have found wide applications in fine-chemical synthesis [1–4], conversion of hydrocarbons [5–7], and environmental catalysis including NO decomposition [8,9], selective reduction of NO [10–12], N2O decomposition [13–17], Fenton’s reaction [18,19], and photo-degradation of dyes [20]. The catalytic performance of ZSM-5 is certainly related to its morphological, structural, and chemical properties. Because different types of catalytic reactions have different requirements of detailed location/distribution of active sites, the synthesis of ZSM-5 with controlled structures/morphologies has become an important task. Seed-induced crystallization has been employed in the synthesis of ZSM-5 with controllable sizes and morphologies [21–23]. However, less attention has been paid to the seed-induced synthesis of “core-shell” structures with ZSM-5 shells. Recently, a seed-induced crystallization method was adopted to prepare Silicalite-1@ZSM-5 core-shell structure, in which Silicalite-1 is the core, and ZSM-5 is the shell [24–26]. It would be interesting to explore the catalytic applications of this type of materials. N2O is a green-house gas and may contribute to the ozone-layer depletion [27]. It can be decomposed at elevated temperatures in the presence of a catalyst such as Cu-ZSM-5 [13–16]. Since catalytic reactions take place on the surface region of heterogeneous catalysts, it would be desirable that the active sites are enriched on the surface region of catalyst particles. In this study, Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5 core-shell particles were prepared by ion exchanging Silicalite-1@ZSM-5 with Cu2+, and the catalytic performance in N2O decomposition was evaluated. Upon appropriate pretreatment in He at 400°C, the catalyst showed higher activity than Cu-ZSM-5 prepared using commercial ZSM-5 as the precursor. The correlation between physicochemical properties and catalytic performance of these catalysts are discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Silicalite-1 seeds Silicalite-1 seeds with an average crystal size of 260nm were synthesized according to a previous work [24]. NaOH was dissolved in an aqueous solution (40wt.%) of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH), and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added. The composition of the mixture was 2.2 (TPA)2O:0.1 Na2O:25 SiO2:1050H2O:100 EtOH. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24h to ensure the complete hydrolysis of TEOS. Afterwards, it was transferred to a polypropylene bottle and hydrothermally treated at 100°C for 3 days, and used directly in the following synthesis without any centrifugation or washing process. 2.2 Seeded synthesis of ZSM-5 Al2(SO4)3·18H2O was dissolved in an aqueous solution of NaOH, and a colloidal SiO2 solution (40wt.%) was added under stirring. The composition was 1.0Al2O3:100SiO2:28Na2O:4000H2O. After the mixture was stirred for 15min, a calculated amount of Silicalite-1 seed suspension was added. The amount (16wt.% adopted here) was calculated by (SiO2 weight in seed sol)/(total SiO2 weight in starting gel)×100%. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 3h, poured into an autoclave, and the autoclave was rotated (30rpm) in an oven at 210°C for 2h. After cooling the autoclave, the final product was separated by filtration and washed with water for 3 times, dried at 80°C for 1 day and then calcinated at 550°C for 6h. The sample synthesized is denoted as ZM-16, where 16 represents the weight percentage (wt.%) of the seed used in the synthesis. 2.3 Cu exchange procedure ZM-16 (1g) was added into 150mL 0.01mol/L Cu(CH3COO)2 solution and stirred at ambient temperature for 24h. Then, the sample was filtrated and washed with water for 3 times and dried at 80°C for 1 day. The ion exchanging procedure was repeated 3 times. After that, the sample was calcinated at 550°C for 6h in flowing air. The obtained sample is denoted as CZM-16. For comparison, NH4-ZSM-5 (Si/Al=30) from Zeolyst was ion-exchanged to Na-ZSM-5 (denoted as ZM-C) by 0.1mol/L NaNO3 solution at room temperature with a solid/liquid ratio of 1:150 for three times, and further exchanged with Cu2+ and calcined. The obtained sample is denoted as CZM-C. 2.4 Characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) experiments were conducted using a Philips XL30 D6716 instrument at an operating voltage of 25kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) experiments were carried out with a JEOL JEM-2010 instrument at an operating voltage of 200kV. Additional TEM-EDS and TEM-mapping experiments were conducted on an FEI Tecani G2 F20 S-Twin instrument. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-rB 12kW diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The Cu contents of catalysts were measured by Inductive Coupled Plasma (ICP) Emission Spectrometer (Themo-6300). The actual Si/Al ratios in the prepared samples were determined by X-ray fluorescence (XRF, ZSX Primus II, Rigaku). Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) with H2 was carried out in a FINETEC FINESORB-3010 apparatus. A 0.12g sample (40–60 mesh) was placed in a U-type quartz tube, pretreated in 50mL/min of He flow at 500°C for 2h and then cooled down to 60°C. The sample was heated to 800°C (ramping rate 10°C/min) under 30mL/min of 10vol.% H2 (balance Ar). The H2 consumption was continuously monitored with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). A cold trap was used to trap water vapor before the gas stream entered the TCD detector. In situ DRIFTS experiments were performed with a FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet 6700) equipped with an MCT detector cooled by liquid N2. A sample was placed in an IR cell fitted with CaF2 windows and heating cartridge. Prior to recording spectra, individual samples from the same batch of catalyst were pretreated in flowing He (50mL/min) at room temperature, 150, 250, or 400°C for 2h and cooled to room temperature. Then 0.2 vol.% CO (balance He) was passed continuously over the samples at room temperature for 1h. Finally, IR spectra with 100 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1 were recorded after the samples were swept under flowing He at room temperature for 1h. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer PHI 5000C spectrometer with MgKα radiation as the excitation source. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of O2 was also performed on the FINETEC FINESORB-3010 apparatus equipped with a TCD detector. 0.15g sample was pre-treated in flowing He (50mL/min) for 2h at 500°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min and then cooled down to room temperature. Afterwards, the sample was treated by flowing O2 (30mL/min) for 1h, and swept with He (30mL/min) to remove physically adsorbed O2. Finally, the sample was heated up to 690°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min under flowing He (30mL/min), and O2 desorbed during the heating was monitored by TCD. 2.5 Catalytic evaluation N2O decomposition was carried out in a U-shape quartz fixed-bed reactor loaded with 0.2g of catalyst. Prior to the reaction testing, the catalyst was pretreated at 500°C in a flow of pure He (50mL/min) for 2h. A gas mixture containing 0.5% N2O in He with a total flow rate of 60mL/min was fed immediately after the catalyst was cooled down to room temperature. After 1h, the reaction temperature was ramped to 100°C, and then the temperature was varied from 100 to 500°C stepwise. At each step, the reaction was stabilized for 0.5h, and the reactor effluent was continuously analyzed online via a gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 7890A) equipped with a TCD detector. The N2O conversion was calculated as ([N2O]in −[N2O]out)/[N2O]in ×100%, where [N2O]in refers to the peak area at room temperature, and [N2O]out refers to the peak area at an elevated temperature. The effect of co-fed O2 and H2O vapor on the catalytic activity was studied by adding 5vol.% O2 or 2vol.% H2O into the reaction mixture whereas the concentration of N2O was still 0.5%, and the total flow rate of the gas was still 60mL/min. The reaction temperature was maintained at 400°C. The stabilities of different catalysts were measured as function of time on stream at 400°C. 3 Results 3.1 Basic physicochemical properties of ZSM-5 samples SEM characterization shows that the ZM-16 sample prepared using Silicalite-1 particles (260nm) as seeds is composed of many particles with diameters on the order of 500nm (Fig. 1 a). Ren et al. have proved the Silicalite-1@ZSM-5 “core-shell” structure, in which Silicalite-1 is the core, and ZSM-5 is the shell [24–26]. An additional TEM image of ZM-16 is shown in Fig. S1 in the Supporting Information. For comparison, the commercial ZM-C is composed of different kinds of aggregates with a very wide range of sizes, and its morphology is less defined (Fig. 1b). XRD characterization indicates that both samples possess typical MFI frameworks (Fig. 2 ). Table 1 summarizes the textual properties and chemical compositions of Cu-ZSM-5 samples prepared using ZM-16 and ZM-C as precursors. CZM-16 shows a bigger surface area (410m2/g) and a larger micropore volume (0.17cm3/g) than CZM-C (290m2/g and 0.10cm3/g, respectively). The Si/Al molar ratios of CZM-16 and CZM-C, determined by XRF, are similar (30 and 31, respectively). The Cu contents of these samples, determined by ICP, are comparable (3.0wt.% and 2.8wt.%, respectively). As shown by TEM-mapping images, Cu species are well dispersed in CZM-16 (Figs. S2 and S3) and CZM-C (Figs. S4 and S5). 3.2 Catalytic activity in N2O decomposition The catalytic decomposition of N2O into N2 and O2 was investigated as a function of reaction temperature. As shown in Fig. 3 , the N2O conversion on CZM-16 increases obviously above 325°C, and is close to 100% at 425°C. For comparison, the N2O conversion on CZM-C increases obviously above 375°C, and reaches 100% at 475°C. The T50 (temperature required for 50% conversion) values of these catalysts are 367 and 421°C, respectively. Considering that the Cu contents of CZM-16 and CZM-C are similar (3.0 and 2.8wt.%, respectively), the obvious difference in their catalytic activity is interesting. The catalytic performance was also compared in another mode, i.e., by testing the N2O conversion at a same temperature (400°C) as a function of reaction time. As shown in Fig. 4 , the initial N2O conversions on CZM-16 and CZM-C at 400°C are 91% and 25%, respectively, close to the values read out from the conversion curves in Fig. 3. The data mean that the activity trend seen in Fig. 3 is reproducible and the activity of different catalysts follows the sequence of CZM-16>CZM-C. Several more samples were tested. As shown in Fig. S6, ZM-16 (i.e., Silicalite-1@ZSM-5) is not active at all. A physical mixture of 0.2g Silicalite-1 and 0.2g CZM-C shows almost the same catalytic activity as 0.2g CZM-C. These data indicate that either Silicalite-1 or Silicalite-1@ZSM-5 (without ion-exchanged Cu species) is not active for N2O decomposition. We additionally prepared Cu-Silicalite-1. The Cu content is only 0.4wt.%, much lower than that (3.0wt.%) of CZM-16. The uptake of Cu on Silicalite-1 is not negligible, probably because the Silicalite-1 still contains a small amount of Al (Table S1). As shown in Fig. S6, Cu-Silicalite-1 shows very low activity, highlighting the advantage of Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5. It should be mentioned that the catalytic activity is related to the Si/Al ratio and Cu content of the catalyst. We additionally prepared CZM-CH using a commercial ZSM-5 with a higher Si/Al ratio (40) as the precursor. As shown in Fig. S7, CZM-CH is less active that CZM-C with a lower Si/Al ratio (31) because the Cu content (2.0wt.%) of the former catalyst is lower than that (2.8wt.%) of the latter. The low Cu content of CZM-CH is caused by the high Si/Al ratio [28]. In addition, CZM-32 (another Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5 sample, 32 represents the weight percentage of the Silicalite-1 seed used in the synthesis of Silicalite-1@ZSM-5) was prepared. The Si/Al ratio (38) is higher than that (30) of CZM-16, and the Cu content (2.2wt.%) of the former catalyst is lower than that (3.0wt.%) of the latter. As shown in Fig. S7, CZM-32 is less active than CZM-16, but is still active than Cu-ZSM-5 prepared using commercial ZSM-5 crystals. Because CZM-16 and CZM-C are more active than CZM-32 and CZM-CH, respectively, the below characterization focuses on the former catalysts. 3.3 CO-IR To clarify the nature of active sites, in situ FT-IR experiments using CO as a probe were conducted. Basically, CO adsorbed on different Cu sites has different IR peaks, thus the peak position of adsorbed CO can indicate the nature of Cu species. As shown in Fig. 5 , the fresh CZM-16 (without being heated in He) does not show any CO peak, because the Cu species at this stage exists in the form of Cu2+, and CO does not adsorb onto Cu2+ at room temperature [29,30]. After CZM-16 is pretreated in He at 150°C and above for 2h, a strong band at 2138cm−1, characteristic of CO adsorbed on dimeric Cu+ (Cu+ COCu+) sites [28,31–33], is observed. A weak shoulder band at 2157cm−1 is attributed to CO adsorbed on isolated Cu+ (Cu+ CO) sites [28,31–35]. These bands increase in intensity as the pretreatment temperature is raised from 150 to 400°C, indicating the further reduction of Cu2+ to dimeric and isolated Cu+. As shown in Fig. 6 , CZM-C pretreated in He at 400°C also contains dimeric Cu+ (Cu+ COCu+) at 2138cm−1 and isolated Cu+ (Cu+ CO) at 2157cm−1. A comparison of the FT-IR data of CZM-16 and CZM-C indicates that the relative area ratio of Cu+ COCu+ band on CZM-16 is significant higher than that on CZM-C (Table 2 ). The implication of the finding will be discussed in Section 4. 3.4 H2-TPR Fig. 7 shows the H2-TPR data of CZM-16 and CZM-C with similar Cu contents. The catalysts were in situ pretreated in He at 500°C for 2h prior to H2-TPR study. They both exhibit three reduction peaks, corresponding to three types of Cu species. A weak reduction peak at 58°C (denoted as peak α) is ascribed to the reduction of oxygen bridged Cu-dimers [CuOCu]2+ to Cu+; the broad reduction peak at 193°C (peak β) corresponds to the reduction of isolated Cu2+ to Cu+ and the reduction of CuO particles to metallic Cu; the intense reduction peak around 400°C (peak γ) is assigned to the reduction of Cu+ to Cu0 [28,36–38]. It is clear that the reduction temperature of peak γ is slightly lower for CZM-C than for CZM-16, indicating that the Cu+ species in CZM-C is easier to be reduced. The amounts of Cu+ species on the pretreated samples, calculated based on the H2 consumption, are summarized in Table 3 . The area of peak β for CZM-16 is comparable to that for CZM-C, whereas the areas of peak α and γ are bigger for CZM-16, meaning that CZM-16 processes more [CuOCu]2+ and Cu+ than CZM-C. On the other hand, the total amounts of Cu on CZM-16 and CZM-C calculated by H2 consumption are close to those detected by ICP. 3.5 O2-TPD As oxygen is one of the products in direct N2O decomposition, its desorption is important for the reaction [39–41]. Fig. 8 shows the baseline-corrected O2-TPD profiles, and the raw data are shown in Fig. S8. CZM-16 and CZM-C both exhibit wide desorption peaks. The initial desorption temperature of CZM-16 is higher than that of CZM-C. However, the area of the desorption peak is obviously lower for CZM-16 (Table 4 ), indicating that the amount of adsorbed O2 is much smaller and the ability of adsorbing O2 is weaker for CZM-16. 3.6 Effect of co-fed O2 or H2O on catalytic performance The effect of periodic step changes of co-fed 5vol.% O2 on the performance of CZM-16 and CZM-C at 400°C are depicted in Fig. 9 a and b. In the first step (0–2h), CZM-16 was exposed to N2O and He (without co-fed O2). The N2O conversion is about 91% at this stage, consistent with the value seen in Fig. 3. However, the introduction of 5vol.% O2 causes a drop of N2O conversion, from 91% to 73% (2–4h). By removing O2, the N2O conversion is recovered. After two cycles, the N2O conversion decreases by 3%. In the first step (0–2h), the N2O conversion on CZM-C is about 25%, consistent with the value seen in Fig. 3. The introduction of 5vol.% O2 causes a drop of N2O conversion, from 26 % to 11 % (2–4h). By removing O2, N2O conversion is partially recovered. After two cycles, the N2O conversion decreases by 10%. The effect of co-fed 2vol.% H2O on the performance of CZM-16 and CZM-C at 400°C are depicted in Fig. 10 a and b. The introduction of 2vol.% H2O can cause a sudden drop of N2O conversion for both catalysts. The catalytic activity can be almost completely restored after removing 2vol.% H2O for CZM-16, but the N2O conversion on CZM-C decreases from 26% to 7% after two cycles. 4 Discussion The activity of Cu-containing zeolites in N2O decomposition has been associated with the presence of Cu species. Here the Cu contents of CZM-16 and CZM-C, determined by ICP, are comparable, i.e., 3.0wt.% and 2.8wt.%, respectively, in line with the similar Si/Al ratios of these catalysts (30 and 31, respectively). This observation confirms that the amounts of Cu2+ exchanged onto the samples are related to the Si/Al ratios. In zeolites, the negative charges of AlO-Si are balanced by Na+ or H+, so the amount of Cu2+ that can exchange with Na+ or H+ on ion-exchange sites of zeolites is related to the amount of framework Al, i.e., the Si/Al ratio [28]. It should be noted that the Si/Al ratio of CZM-16 (30) is much lower than that in starting gel (50), i.e., the concentration of Al in the starting gel is low, but now Al is enriched in the ZSM-5 shell of CZM-16. Therefore, the density of Al in the shell region is supposed to be higher than that in CZM-C. The enrichment of Al in the shell region may also lead to the enrichment of Cu species there, because the uptake of Cu species on Silicalite-1 particles is quite low (Table S1). This is proved by the CO-IR data which show that the dimeric Cu+/isolated Cu+ ratio for CZM-16 pretreated in He at 400°C is more than three times larger than that for CZM-C (Table 3). Our H2-TPR data also confirm this point. In addition, both TEM-EDS and XPS data show the presence of more Cu species on the surface of CZM-16 (Figs. S9-S14). The presence of more dimetric Cu+ on CZM-16 means that the distance between Cu+ cations is shorter. Cu+ in zeolites is commonly regarded as the active site for N2O decomposition [39,42–44], and oxygen-oxygen recombination is widely perceived as the rate-limiting step [41,45–47]. Oxygen atoms can easily recombine without migration over the surface of CZM-16 with a high dimeric Cu+ amount. Therefore, dimeric Cu+ shows higher activity than isolated Cu+ in N2O decomposition [41,44,48]. O2-TPD data show that the amount of adsorbed (and hence desorbed) O2 of CZM-16 is significantly smaller than that of CZM-C (Table 4). As the desorption of adsorbed oxygen plays an important role in N2O decomposition, the weak ability of adsorbing O2 may facilitate N2O decomposition. This may be another reason for the higher activity of CZM-16. O2 can decrease the activity of both CZM-16 and CZM-C to some extent, but the inhibiting effect is reversible for CZM-16, i.e., the N2O conversion is almost restored after retracting O2. This indicates that the active Cu species of CZM-16 show better anti-oxidation ability in oxygen atmosphere. On the other hand, the inhibiting effect of H2O vapor is more obvious, due to the competition between N2O and H2O for active sites [48]. The inhibiting effect of H2O is reversible for CZM-16, but that is less reversible for CZM-C, probably due to the sintering of Cu ions or dealumination of Cu-ZSM-5 [48–50]. After 50h reaction, the N2O conversions on CZM-16 and CZM-C decrease by 5% and 9%, respectively (Fig. 4). In situ CO-IR data indicate Cu+ species are the active sites, because Cu+ species are dominance species for He-activated catalysts and spent catalysts collected after reaction testing (Fig. 6). The oxidation of a portion of Cu+ by O2 produced by N2O decomposition may be responsible for the decrease of N2O conversion. The amount of Cu+ in CZM-16 decrease less obviously than that in CZM-C (Fig. 6), which explains the better stability of CZM-16. 5 Conclusions Two Cu-exchanged zeolite catalysts were synthesized. CZM-16 was prepared using Silicalite-1@ZSM-5 core-shell particles. CZM-C was prepared using commercial ZSM-5 as the precursor. Although they have similar Cu contents (3.0wt.% and 2.8wt.%, respectively), CZM-16 has more dimetric Cu+ than CZM-C upon thermal pretreatment in He. In addition, less O2 is adsorbed on CZM-16. Both factors contribute to the much higher activity of CZM-16. CZM-16 shows good stability on stream. The co-fed O2 or H2O can decrease the activity of both catalysts, but the inhibiting effect is reversible for CZM-16. Although here we only studied N2O decomposition, we believe that it would be interesting to study the applications of this type of core-shell zeolite catalysts in other reactions. coredata.dc:description: Silicalite-1 particles with an average size of 260nm were used as seeds to prepare Silicalite-1@ZSM-5 core-shell crystals with sizes on the order of 500nm. A Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5 catalyst was then prepared by ion exchange with copper acetate. Upon appropriate pretreatment in He at 500°C, the core-shell catalyst showed much higher activity in N2O decomposition than Cu-ZSM-5 prepared using commercial ZSM-5 as the precursor. Characterization of relevant samples was conducted employing N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, ICP, XRF, SEM, TEM, XPS, CO-IR, H2-TPR, and O2-TPR. It was found that Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5 has more dimetric Cu+ upon thermal pretreatment in He. In addition, less O2 can be adsorbed on Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5. Both factors contribute to the much higher activity of Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5. The effect of co-fed O2 and H2O vapor on the catalytic performance was also studied.
coredata.dc:title: Silicalite-1@Cu-ZSM-5 core-shell catalyst for N2O decomposition
